comment: I played this quickly but I had been thinking about whether or not to do it ever since I found out who my opponent was, i.e. about five minutes before the game. The point is that against the Winawer I play a slightly offbeat line, and pretty successfully, but I was afraid that it wouldn't hold up against a GM. This line is less ambitious, but it makes him think about how to make the game interesting.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. Nf3 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6
comment: This is what I wanted, and now I can go back into d4 lines.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. Nf3 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. e5 Nfd7 5. d4 c5 6. dxc5 Bxc5 7. Bd3 Nc6 8. Bf4 f6 9. Qe2
comment: I was aware that black can probably equalize immediately now with 9... fe 10.Nxe5 Nxe5 11.Bxe5 Nxe5 12.Qxe5 Qf6. However I was also fairly confident that I would give him a hell of a time trying to beat me in the endgame, where I felt more confident of my abilities than in French-style complications that he is probably very familiar with. So this is a decision based mainly on off-the-board considerations.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. Nf3 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. e5 Nfd7 5. d4 c5 6. dxc5 Bxc5 7. Bd3 Nc6 8. Bf4 f6 9. Qe2 fxe5 10. Nxe5 Ndxe5 11. Bxe5 Nxe5 12. Qxe5 O-O
comment: He doesn't want to play the endgame either. Good.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. Nf3 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. e5 Nfd7 5. d4 c5 6. dxc5 Bxc5 7. Bd3 Nc6 8. Bf4 f6 9. Qe2 fxe5 10. Nxe5 Ndxe5 11. Bxe5 Nxe5 12. Qxe5 O-O 13. Rf1
comment: This cost me a lot of time. I saw the more obvious 13.O-O-O first, but I didn't feel there was enough for the pawn yet. Then it hit me that it might be best to keep the pawn for one more move and let black decide what to do in the mean time. Nonetheless, the move is a mistake because in actual fact I do not get enough for the pawn even after 14.O-O-O.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. Nf3 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. e5 Nfd7 5. d4 c5 6. dxc5 Bxc5 7. Bd3 Nc6 8. Bf4 f6 9. Qe2 fxe5 10. Nxe5 Ndxe5 11. Bxe5 Nxe5 12. Qxe5 O-O 13. Rf1 g6
comment: Definitely a creative response. I'm still not sure exactly what black's idea is, but I have a couple of guesses. One is that he wants to play ...Bd6 with tempo since I will not be able to reply Qh5.  There is also an idea that, strangely, he did not try to implement in the game.  In rough form it is to play ...Bxf2, Bc5, Bxf8, Bg7, etc. In any case, it seems to me that this is one of the more relavent things he can do with his time, compared to 13...a6, for example.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. Nf3 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. e5 Nfd7 5. d4 c5 6. dxc5 Bxc5 7. Bd3 Nc6 8. Bf4 f6 9. Qe2 fxe5 10. Nxe5 Ndxe5 11. Bxe5 Nxe5 12. Qxe5 O-O 13. Rf1 g6 14. O-O-O Bxf2 15. Kb1 Bd7 16. Ne4
comment: This was my original idea and an interesting one. Unfortunately here I missed a straghtforward chance to beat a GM...

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. Nf3 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. e5 Nfd7 5. d4 c5 6. dxc5 Bxc5 7. Bd3 Nc6 8. Bf4 f6 9. Qe2 fxe5 10. Nxe5 Ndxe5 11. Bxe5 Nxe5 12. Qxe5 O-O 13. Rf1 g6 14. O-O-O Bxf2 15. Kb1 Bd7 16. Ne4 dxe4
comment: He played this quickly, presumably happy because in the ending he is not likely to lose, i.e. the old "playing for two results"... yet Fritz found another spoiler.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. Nf3 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. e5 Nfd7 5. d4 c5 6. dxc5 Bxc5 7. Bd3 Nc6 8. Bf4 f6 9. Qe2 fxe5 10. Nxe5 Ndxe5 11. Bxe5 Nxe5 12. Qxe5 O-O 13. Rf1 g6 14. O-O-O Bxf2 15. Kb1 Bd7 16. Ne4 dxe4 17. Bc4 Qf6 18. Qxf6 Rxf6 19. Rxd7
comment: Reaching an interesting endgame. White can try to take advantage of his active rook to recover material, but I chose another plan. Basically it consists of playing like a pansy and holding the fort at e2. Since black's extra pawn is crippled, I think this offers excellent chances of getting a draw.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. Nf3 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. e5 Nfd7 5. d4 c5 6. dxc5 Bxc5 7. Bd3 Nc6 8. Bf4 f6 9. Qe2 fxe5 10. Nxe5 Ndxe5 11. Bxe5 Nxe5 12. Qxe5 O-O 13. Rf1 g6 14. O-O-O Bxf2 15. Kb1 Bd7 16. Ne4 dxe4 17. Bc4 Qf6 18. Qxf6 Rxf6 19. Rxd7 e3 20. c3
comment: Sticking to the plan. I wasn't even interested in surrendering the d-file for a pawn.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. Nf3 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. e5 Nfd7 5. d4 c5 6. dxc5 Bxc5 7. Bd3 Nc6 8. Bf4 f6 9. Qe2 fxe5 10. Nxe5 Ndxe5 11. Bxe5 Nxe5 12. Qxe5 O-O 13. Rf1 g6 14. O-O-O Bxf2 15. Kb1 Bd7 16. Ne4 dxe4 17. Bc4 Qf6 18. Qxf6 Rxf6 19. Rxd7 e3 20. c3 Rc8 21. Be2 Rf7 22. Rxf7 Kxf7 23. Kc2 Ke7 24. Rd1 Rc5
comment: Black's winning idea is to encourage me to move my pawns. For example after g3 he can think about ...h7-h5-h4, while h3 might allow something like ...Kg3 ...Rxf3 (presumably I will put my bishop on f3). Another point is that I can probably afford pawn moves on one side if my king stays on that side.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. Nf3 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. e5 Nfd7 5. d4 c5 6. dxc5 Bxc5 7. Bd3 Nc6 8. Bf4 f6 9. Qe2 fxe5 10. Nxe5 Ndxe5 11. Bxe5 Nxe5 12. Qxe5 O-O 13. Rf1 g6 14. O-O-O Bxf2 15. Kb1 Bd7 16. Ne4 dxe4 17. Bc4 Qf6 18. Qxf6 Rxf6 19. Rxd7 e3 20. c3 Rc8 21. Be2 Rf7 22. Rxf7 Kxf7 23. Kc2 Ke7 24. Rd1 Rc5 25. Bf3 b5 26. Kd3
comment: Plan A is to put the king on e2 and avoid moving my queenside pawns, which will become feasible if I can get in a3 and Rd4.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. Nf3 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. e5 Nfd7 5. d4 c5 6. dxc5 Bxc5 7. Bd3 Nc6 8. Bf4 f6 9. Qe2 fxe5 10. Nxe5 Ndxe5 11. Bxe5 Nxe5 12. Qxe5 O-O 13. Rf1 g6 14. O-O-O Bxf2 15. Kb1 Bd7 16. Ne4 dxe4 17. Bc4 Qf6 18. Qxf6 Rxf6 19. Rxd7 e3 20. c3 Rc8 21. Be2 Rf7 22. Rxf7 Kxf7 23. Kc2 Ke7 24. Rd1 Rc5 25. Bf3 b5 26. Kd3 Kf6 27. a3 a5 28. b4
comment: Plan B. The queenside pawns move after all, and my king returns to its post on c2. The rook ends up miserably defending b5 so my kingside is safe.

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. Nf3 d5 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. e5 Nfd7 5. d4 c5 6. dxc5 Bxc5 7. Bd3 Nc6 8. Bf4 f6 9. Qe2 fxe5 10. Nxe5 Ndxe5 11. Bxe5 Nxe5 12. Qxe5 O-O 13. Rf1 g6 14. O-O-O Bxf2 15. Kb1 Bd7 16. Ne4 dxe4 17. Bc4 Qf6 18. Qxf6 Rxf6 19. Rxd7 e3 20. c3 Rc8 21. Be2 Rf7 22. Rxf7 Kxf7 23. Kc2 Ke7 24. Rd1 Rc5 25. Bf3 b5 26. Kd3 Kf6 27. a3 a5 28. b4 axb4 29. axb4 Rc7 30. Kc2 Ke5 31. Be2 Rb7
comment: He offered a draw here. Only white can play to win, but if I do so with, for example, Ra1, then ...Rd7 gives black chances too.
